utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
These are the Babushkas of Buranova.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Buranova is a tiny village 600 miles east of Moscow.
I went there last year to meet a dozen or so women who were making quite a name for themselves.
They treated me to this song as I walked into one of their homes.
Babushka is Russian for grandmother and these women are mostly in their 70s and 80s.
Their story is sadly familiar in Russia.
Many of these elderly women lost their husbands years ago to alcoholism or hard work.
Searching for companionship, the babushkas of Buranova turned to one another and to music.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
But their music took an odd turn.
A few years ago, a producer from Moscow heard about the singing group and hatched a plan.
If they would be willing to sing catchy Western songs in their native Udmurt language, they might gain quite a following.
The women agreed, performing Queen, The Eagles.
Here, the Beatles.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
They became an Internet sensation, and this year, they represented Russia at the Eurovision world music competition in Azerbaijan.
The little ladies, smiling at one another on stage, didn't end up winning, but really, they stole the show.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
When I met the women, they were enjoying their fame, but talked mostly about wanting to help their ramshackle village.
Above all, they wanted to rebuild a church that was destroyed during Stalinist times.
Any small money they got from their performances, they told me, was set aside for the church.
Which is why I smiled a few days ago, catching a story in the New York Times from Buranova.
Work on the church has finally begun.
What's more, the local government is laying a new water pipeline in the village.
They're rebuilding roads and putting in high-speed Internet.
One resident said God had forgotten this place until the babushkas sang...
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
You're listening to NPR News.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
And here are headlines from some of the stories we're following here today at NPR News.
China today announced a $586 billion economic stimulus package.
The plan calls for more government investment in the country's infrastructure, tax deductions for exporters, and subsidies for farmers and the poor.
And singer Miriam Makeba, whose voice gave South Africans hope when the country was gripped by apartheid, died today.
She was 76.
We'll remember her life and her music in a few minutes.
And you can hear details on both those stories coming up later today on All Things Considered.
Tomorrow in this hour on Talk of the Nation, a nightmare for any family.
A 12-year-old boy pronounced brain dead but still breathing with help from a machine.
Devout parents argue that under their religious views, their son is still alive.
Doctors say that's inhumane to keep him alive and want to go to court to stop treatment.
We'll look at the issue of life or death, who decides.
Plus, all the things we won't miss from the election.
That's tomorrow's Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
For the past four years, U.S.
Special Forces conducted numerous raids against al-Qaeda and other militant groups inside countries not at war with the United States.
Recent attacks in Pakistan and Syria became public, others remained secret.
The New York Times reports today that these military raids, usually coordinated and conducted with the CIA, took place not just in Syria and Pakistan but in Somalia and other countries, too.
They were authorized by a classified order signed by then Secretary of Defense, Donald Rumsfeld and approved by President Bush in the spring of 2004.
Mark Mazetti co-wrote today's front page story with Eric Schmitt.
And Mark joins us now from a studio here in Washington.
Nice to have you on the program, Mark.
Thanks for having me on.

In one of this scenes - these raids you described as a scene almost like from a movie, Navy Seals crossed the border into Pakistan and raided a village while officials in Washington watched real time from a camera on a predator drone flying above.
That's right.

We're told that the special operations troops were attacking a compound inside the mountainous tribal areas and that they - there was an agreement that they needed to actually have people on the ground to conduct this raid as opposed to just doing a predator air strike which has just been happening a lot in the tribal areas.
So yeah, the technology is quite something that allows them all to watch in real time.

And there was also - in addition to the raids, you report several others, at least, where their missions were scrubbed because of either diplomatic problems or because of concerns over poor intelligence?
That's right.
We reported today that even after this execute order, as they're called, that gave authorities to do these kinds of missions, they still needed to be approved.
And so, it allowed the Pentagon to sort of gather intelligence and to draw up mission plans to do these kind of raids.
But ultimately, they had to get approvals from the highest levels of government.
And in the case that we described in the story today, it was a suspected militant meeting of al-Qaeda leaders, possibly with Ayman al-Zawahiri, the number two in al-Qaeda.
And ultimately, it was scrubbed at the last minute because they felt they weren't 100 percent sure he was there, and it may have just been too risky.

Indeed, the pope had some questions to answer about his actions, when as Cardinal Ratzinger, he was asking, well, people Catholic officials all across the world to basically keep quiet about these things.
Absolutely.
And when the Xerox copier arrived around 1950, 1960, you could copy books and joke drawings and poems and whatnot and send it in the mail.
Publishers at that time wanted to ban the Xerox copier because you could do this, but no politicians would dare suggest that you open all the mails and look for copyright infringements.
Still, this is what's being suggested online.
It's simply that the right to communicate in private takes precedence over copyright.
And you call yourself the Pirate Party.
I mean, you're not a gimmick.
I mean, this isn't a joke.
You're for real.
Well, we are very much for real in the European Parliament.
And who's in the party?
I mean, who are your members?
About two-thirds are creators of some sort, coders, musicians, writers, translators.
The rest are mostly civil liberties activists.
And your numbers are growing.
They're growing phenomenally.
I mean, we're 50,000 members, 17,000 activists.
We're growing at - I wouldn't say an alarming rate but a steady rate.
I mean, alarming to I guess the music industry.
You're now the third largest political party in Sweden.
That's true.
Now there are also pirate parties forming all over Europe.
Are you sort of spreading the word throughout the continent?
I guess we're sort of the ice breaker.
We're showing people that you can actually do this.
I mean, our campaign budget for the 2009 elections was $50,000.
That alone should scare the established politicians.
If nothing else, the fact that we are the largest party for citizens below 30 years of age should scare the established politicians.
Mr.
Falkvinge, thanks very much.
Thank you.
Rick Falkvinge is the founder of Sweden's Pirate Party.
That party will seat its first delegate Christian Engstrom in Europe's parliament this July.

This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
There have been some dramatic moves by the government this week to intervene in the ongoing credit crisis.
The Federal Reserve saved Bear Stearns from a messy bankruptcy on Sunday.
It also changed its rule book to extend credit to Wall Street investment banks for the first time.
Today, regulators freed up the lending giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to spend billions more dollars to get the mortgage market moving again.
But the underlying problem remains.
Millions of homeowners still face foreclosure and that could still push the economy into a severe recession.
Now, there are signs that lawmakers in Washington are prepared to do more, as NPR's Chris Arnold reports.
When the Fed acted to stop a total collapse of Bear Stearns this week, it stepped over a line that it hadn't crossed before in this crisis.
It put itself on the hook for some of the bad investments made by Bear Stearns.
That marks a shift in how far the government's willing to go to intervene here.
What's changed is that policymakers now think that government should put itself on the line; taxpayer money should be put up.
Mark Zandi heads up MoodysEconomy.com.
He's an economist who's been meeting with officials of the Fed, the Treasury Department, and with members of Congress.

He says more of them are now advocating, or at least considering, basically doing for homeowners what the Fed did for investment banks; that is, take on the risk itself for at least some of the bad loans that are out there.
This was obviously a very extreme idea just the few weeks ago, but now is well into the mainstream.
The Congress and the administration are thinking that lots of economists, including myself, are suggesting that this should in fact happen.
The idea behind some of the proposals is that they probably wouldn't cost the government that much and they'd save the economy from much bigger problems.
Congressman Barney Frank.
We need to reduce the amount of foreclosures coming, because the economy can't recover until we do that.
